<lj-template name="qotd" id="928" />

When people are too lazy to recycle and when there are no recycling bins. My high school had tons of bottles and cans, but no recycling bins. FAIL.

I hate Napoleon Dynamite, the Fullmetal Alchemist movie, The Time Traveler's Wife, and Friends apart from the normal dislike of the Jonas Brothers, Miley Cyrus, tweens, Abercrombie and Fitch, Banana Republic, and My Super Sweet Sixteen.
In which I am a Bear Builder AND a bagger! Hell yeah!
In which I chose the optimistic path.

<lj-template name="qotd" id="811" />

I humiliate myself. And don't come after those that reference humiliating moments from the past.
Also, things just happen around me. I don't know if irony follows you, but if it does, I'm pretty sure I've got a stalker...

I've been doin' shit, man.

Begin at the beginning and go on till you come to the end; then stop. -Lewis Carroll I've learned that, over the past two weeks, that life's ironies are to just be taken in with an inhalation and an exhalation. Mild side effects include dizziness, nausea, drama, altered state of mind, and insanity. Please mind the gap.

<lj-template name="qotd" id="787" />

The place I want to go cannot be reached. :\

TODAY was the best day ever!! I got thrown into the school pool with my clothes on.
And I wore the dress that I made over the weekend.
And I bought a lot of energy drinks.
And I am going to college. 
And I had a really good day. :)

2008 is finally coming to a close. It's been a pretty eventful year. 
Hopefully 2009 is as much fun!
In which I helped fight breast cancer.

<lj-template name="qotd" id="554" />

It depends on how intermixed they are. America is not a theocracy. Despite how much some people want it to be, it isn't. There are too many different people to have to be a theocracy. 
As a Christian, I do support the basics being intermixed. (But then again, so does everybody). Those being don't murder, steal, etc. If I turn the tables and imagine crazyass Tom Cruise as our prez, I wouldn't want him shoving his beliefs at me. 

Basically, there is no answer to this question because everybody, to me, has a religion. The absence of religion is a religion. Judaism, Islam, Wicca... any belief that answers the fundamental questions of life is a "religion" to me because it requires at least a bit of faith. 

Conclusion to long blurb: There will never be a solution because nobody will agree on it. Religion is too close and personal for people to make concessions and SIU.

Stunna shades: $10

Rap song from iTunes: $1

Gas for drive: $5

Realizing that you are, in fact, white: Priceless
In which I awaited the part where the credits rolled.
In which I made a packing list, waited patiently outwardly but was secretly very impatient for the coming weekend, and ate a grilled cheese.
In which I was no longer afraid, stood on the threshold of summer, and made plum cake.
In which I looked forward to the weekend, grilled over fifty brats and hot dogs, played Powderpuff football, and had a young and stupid night.

lkasj;lgkjel;kjag;lskjgekjgkgj;lekaj;lksgj;kgj;elk x39085739085703

[in which I spazzed on the keyboard because of the Avatar trailer]
In which there were hints of summer and spring came, so I felt very very happy.
In which it snowed, so I cleaned.

So I'm a sewing-pattern virgin, but hopefully no longer!
I went to the fabric store and got one for $2. 
Half-Price books was a few feet away, so I stopped and bought a new Bible with notations in it and a book of Spanish poetry.

I watched Only Yesterday. I loved it. It was better than Grave of the Fireflies, in which I cried my eyes out.
In which I decided to not just survive.

Mi vida es amor.

No other words.

In which I wanted to live the college life, played Ultimate Frisbee, used chopsticks, watched Nightmare Before Christmas on Halloween (appropriately), and ate a part of a large fruit tart. 
It was all heavenly. And I'd live in Liz's dorm for a very long time.
In which I painted, raced in a cardboard boat, applied Boyle's Law, overate, and recharged a tired cell phone.

Orchestra music, the new Sewing machine that does squiggly stitches, and Darjeeling tea all make life worthwhile....
along with many other things. :)
In which stupid people came to Build a Bear, I went to the dentist, and ate a Pixie Stick for dinner.
In which I played the Spill Canvas loudly, read H.P. Lovecraft, and painted over memories.
In which I decided to run away to Paris.
In which I realized there is a fabulous destiny.
In which I ate Lemonheads, discussed topics, pretended to surf, and dubbed my car a safe haven.
In which I cut down my work schedule, bounced around with the Build a Bear crew, bought a purple dress, & avoided telemarketers.
In which I worked a lot and ate ramen.
In which I picked up an Xbox controller & spoke "I've missed you", ate half a tub of yogurt, and listened to Four Letter Lie.
In which I cannot understand physics and pre-calc, cursed the stupid customers, and didn't prepare for a speech.
In which orientation was a hassle, new rules were introduced and then dismissed, there were golf bags in the backseat of my car, and I referred to 'our' car as 'my' car.
In which I got a set schedule, colored with crayons (in a stolen coloring book from Build a Bear!!), and still had a messy room.
In which I have two jobs, a new bulk of worry, a messy room, and went to another show at Shorewood.

So, I made a purse out of a Hello Kitty shirt and drank an entire case of ginger beer. It's delicious and legal; I built about a bazillion bears. 
Those are my summer accomplishments.

I've decided to blast Lust A Prima Vista & clean.
Then have another peanut-butter-and-Nutella sandwich while watching Family Guy.

Tomorrow I begin school shopping and wrapping up summer like it was a gift.
Bad analogies. I really need an English lesson.

So, I've almost finished with Eclipse, third in the Twilight Series... or whatever it's called.
And, like Harry Potter, I just want to jump into the book & strangle Bella.
But it's a good book so far. Better than New Moon, not better than Twilight. Maybe the same level...

In which I decided to live out August with marathons of Bleach, was scheduled to work five days in a row, and listened to to-ta-lee r-aaaa-d music.
I went to the LCMS National Youth Gathering and gained a new perspective; hopefully it won't wear off and fade because I love it.

He was good. Then he died.
AUGH!!
In which I fell off a tire swing, decided to get over "it", and wore a sweatshirt.
